00029 /**
00030 Main documentation information. Contains no code!
00031 @file mainpage.h
00032 @date 27-Jan-2010
00033 @author Se√°n Harte
00034 @mainpage
00035 
00036 Instructions for using the Tyndall USB Programmer
00037 
00038 @par Installation
00039 
00040     The executable file @e tynprog.exe should be placed in a directory that is
00041     in the PATH system variable. An easy way to do this is to copy it to the
00042     @e utils/bin directory of WinAVR.
00043 
00044     The latest FTDI drivers should be installed. These can be found here:
00045     http://www.ftdichip.com/FTDrivers.htm. Version 2.06.00 is known to work, but
00046     other versions should be ok too.
00047 
00048     If there are problems with @e tynprog.exe, tynprog_oss.exe can be used
00049     instead. This version does not require the FTDI drivers, but requires the
00050     open source software @e libusb filter driver to be installed:
00051     http://libusb-win32.sourceforge.net/#installation
00052     In order to use this version from within Programmer's Notepad, it should be
00053     renamed to @e tynprog.exe, replacing the other version.
00054 
00055     The EEPROM in the FT232R chip must be programmed before @e tynprog.exe can
00056     recognise the board. This should be done when the board is first assembled,
00057     and will only need to be done once. The file @e Tyndall25mmProg.xml (for
00058     25mm USB boards) or @e Tyndall10mmProg.xml must be programmed using FTProg:
00059     http://www.ftdichip.com/Resources/Utilities.htm
00060 
00061 
00062 @par Usage
00063 
00064     Connect the Tyndall USB programming board, with the transceiver layer that
00065     you want to program, to the PC/laptop. Note that it is not possible to
00066     program the 25mm Nordic nRF2401 board, or the 25mm ZigBee revA board using
00067     USB. This is because the SPI clock pin is not available on the connector.
00068 
00069     Make sure the power switch on the programming board is in the correct
00070     position.
00071 
00072     @e tynprog.exe can be called from Programmer's Notepad using the @e [WinAVR]
00073     Program command in the tools menu. To do this the @c PROG_PORT variable in
00074     @e apps/makerules should be set to @c USB, e.g.:
00075     @code PROG_PORT = USB @endcode
00076 
00077     @e tynprog.exe can also be called from the command line. Some examples for
00078     setting fuses, writing program code to Flash memory, and reading back the
00079     EEPROM:
00080     @code    tynprog.exe -m atmega_fuses -w FF91EF @endcode
00081     @code    tynprog.exe -w atmega_flash -w adcToRf.bin @endcode
00082     @code    tynprog.exe -m atmega_eeprom -r eeprom.bin @endcode
00083     @code    tynprog.exe -m nrf9e5 -i -w app.bin @endcode
00084     @code    tynprog.exe -m nrf9e5 -e @endcode
00085 
00086     @e tynprog.exe works with only with raw binary files. Some compilers may
00087     only generate intel-hex formatted files. The tool @e srec_cat that is
00088     installed with WinAVR can be used to convert between the formats.
00089 
00090     To convert from hex to binary (replace file1.* with real filenames):
00091     @code    srec_cat file1.hex --intel -o file1.bin -binary @endcode
00092 
00093     To convert from binary to hex (replace file1.* with real filenames):
00094     @code    srec_cat file1.bin --binary -o file1.hex -intel @endcode
00095 
00096     If a 25mm board is being programmed for the first time, the @c '-s' option
00097     must be used, as the default clock frequency is 1MHz which is not fast
00098     enough for full speed communication.
00099 
00100     A header is always added when programming a 10mm board. This header is 
00101     necessary for the nRF9E5 to be able to read the memory correctly. A file
00102     which contains the actual content that is programmed to the board is output
00103     called @e nrf9e5_out.bin.
00104 
00105     Note that only one device can be programmed at a time, and therefore only
00106     one programming board should be connected before programming.
00107 
00108 @par Command-line Options
00109 
00110 @verbatim
00111  Usage: tynprog [options]
00112 
00113  Options:
00114    -c <frequency>     Value in MHz for crystal oscillator frequency. This is
00115                       only for the nRF9E5. Valid values are 4, 8, 12, 16 or 20.
00116                       If this option is not used, 20 will be assumed.
00117 
00118    -e                 Erases memory.
00119 
00120    -h                 Print this help message.
00121 
00122    -i                 To allow support for in-system reprogramming.
00123 
00124    -m <memory type>   Select memory that will be written to. Valid options are:
00125                       nrf9e5, atmega_flash, atmega_eeprom, or atmega_fuses.
00126 
00127    -r <file>          Read memory and store it in <file> (in binary format).
00128                       Overwrites any existing file of the same name.
00129 
00130    -s                 Use very slow clock speed for programming (9600 bits/s).
00131 
00132    -w <file>          Write <file> to memory with verification.
00133 
00134  Only one operation (erase, read, or write) can be performed in a single
00135  execution.
00136 
00137  For fuses, replace <file> with <ext_byte><high_byte><low_byte>. Example fuse
00138  settings to use the internal 8MHz clock are FF91E4 for Atmega128, and FF91E2
00139  for ATmega1281.
00140 
00141  The format of the file type is raw binary. External tools should be used to
00142  convert to/from other formats (e.g. Intel-Hex format).
00143 
00144  Only one device can be programmed at a time.
00145 @endverbatim
00146 
00147 
00148 @par Information for Developers
00149 
00150     This software works by interfacing with the FT232R chip, which has eight
00151     pins that can be used for bit-banging. This software communicates with the
00152     FT232R through the API provided by the D2XX device drivers. An array of
00153     bytes is passed to the FT232R and appears as parallel data on the eight
00154     pins, each of which can be set to be an input (high-impedance) or an output.
00155     The logic value of each pin can is also read back every time the pins are
00156     written to. This allows bi-directional communication.
00157 
00158     In order to access the API, the files @e ftd2xx.h and @e ftd2xx.lib
00159     (available with the drivers) must be put in the same folder as the source
00160     files, and @e ftd2xx.lib must be linked to when compiling. 
00161 
00162     Alternatively, the FT232R can be accessed by the functions in libftdi. These
00163     functions are described and implemented in @e ftdi.h and @e ftdi.c, which
00164     are available from http://www.intra2net.com/en/developer/libftdi/. libftdi 
00165     uses libusb to perform the actual interaction with the chip. This must be
00166     installed on the PC where the programmer will run. The functions in libusb
00167     are detailed in @e usb.h, and the library @e libusb.a must be linked to when
00168     compiling. The libusb driver, and other files are available from
00169     http://libusb-win32.sourceforge.net/
00170     
00171     To build with the D2XX driver, @c FTDI_USE_D2XX must be defined when
00172     compiling, @e ftd2xx.lib must be linked to, and @e ftd2xx.h should be in the
00173     same folder as other files.
00174 
00175     To build with libftdi and libusb, @c FTDI_USE_LIBUSB must be defined when
00176     compiling, @e libusb.a must be linked to, @e ftdi.c should be compiled and
00177     linked to, and @e ftdi.h and @e usb.h should be in the same folder as other
00178     files.
00179     
00180     The CodeLite IDE (http://codelite.org/) has been successfully used to
00181     compile this, and a workspace file is included with the sources files
00182     (@e tynprog.workspace). This workspace contains two projects for linking
00183     with D2XX or libusb / libftdi.
00184 
00185     The bit-banging mechanism is used to communicate with the target
00186     microcontroller using the SPI protocol. The functions for this are in
00187     @e ft_spi.h. Each microcontroller (AVR ATmegaXXX, and nRF9E5) uses different
00188     commands to control programming, so requires their own implementation of a
00189     programming interface. This is done in the @e atmega.c and @e nrf9e5.c
00190     files. The interface itself is defined by the @c spiDeviceInfo_t structure
00191     in @e common.h. Any new microcontrollers for which suppport is added should
00192     provide the same set of commands to allow them to be easily integrated, and
00193     @e tynprog.c shouldn't need to be modified.
00194 
00195     There is a significant delay every time the FT232R is accessed. In order to
00196     speed-up the operation of the application, the number of calls to the
00197     functions in @e ft_spi.h should be reduced as much as possible. This may
00198     require buffering commands and sending them all at once.
00199

00206     free.
00207
